questions.text: Light entering the eye first passes through ______ retinal layer.
questions.solution:
Light passes first through the retinal ganglion layer, the most anterior/inner layer of the retina. Light then passes through other layers of the retina until it reaches the photoreceptors in the posterior/outer region of the retina. 

Retina is organized into 10 layers or zones where distinctive components are clustered together to form continuous strata. 

  • Light passes in the direction: Vitreous humor(anterior)→ choroid(most posterior) encountering the cell layers in that direction (ganglion cell layer→photoreceptors)
  • Visual processing/Phototransduction occurs in the opposite direction (Photoreceptors→ ganglion cell layer)
 

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  1. Internal limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with_____

choices.text: Condensation of opsin with Vitamin A
Photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple

questions.solution:
Initiation of visual impulse is associated with photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple

Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.

questions.text: Which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to make rhodopsin?
questions.solution:
11-cis –retinaldehyde combines with opsin to make rhodopsin.

All-trans retinol is one form of Vitamin A which is converted to 11-cis retinol under the influence of Isomerase. Finally, 11-cis retinol is converted into 11-cis retinal which combines with Scotopsin to form rhodopsin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding distribution of rods and cones in retina?

choices.text: Macula lutea is the blind spot
low density of photoreceptors are present in macula
Peripheral retina has greater cones to rods ratio

questions.solution:
Central fovea (foveola) contains only cones (rod-free area) and is a region of highest resolution.

Regional Variations in the Retina

Macula lutea

  • Located at posterior pole, temporal to the optic disc
  • Area of central vision
  • High density of photoreceptors and interneurons

Optic disc

  • Lacks photoreceptors
  • Is called “Blind spot”
  • Normally a person is unaware of blind spot because
    • Corresponding part of the visual field can be seen by the contralateral eye
    • Neurological processes complete the incomplete image perceptually

Peripheral retina

  • Higher ratio of rods to cones =Rod to cone→20:1
  • Greater degree of convergence of photoreceptors to the target interneuron (bipolar cells)
    • More sensitivity to light
    • Lower visual acuity

questions.text: The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows ______.
questions.solution:
The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows hyperpolarization.

In most sensory receptors: Arrival of stimulus → Ion channels are opened up allowing current to flow => depolarisation of the receptor.

In photoreceptors: When the light strikes the outer segment, a cascade of reactions (refer figure) are initiated, that close some of the Na+ channels in the outer segment and results in hyperpolarization.

questions.text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Photoreceptors - rods and cones are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.

End of controversy! The latest edition of Yanoff & Duker, mentions the photo-receptors as the first order neurons.

Related Pearl: Order of neurons in the visual pathway

Order of neurons in the visual pathway

First-order neurons

Photoreceptors
(rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Third-order neurons

Ganglion cells
(optic nerve)

Fourth-order neurons

Axons from the lateral geniculate body
(optic radiation)

questions.text: Purely depolarizing cells in optic pathway are ______
questions.solution: The responses of the rods, cones, and horizontal cells are hyperpolarizing, and the responses of the bipolar cells are either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing, whereas amacrine cells produce purely depolarizing potential.

questions.text: Amacrine cells secrete_____
questions.solution:
Amacrine cells release acetylcholine.

Amacrine cells are one of the neuronal cell types of the retina. They transmit signals in two directions, either directly from bipolar cells to ganglion cells or horizontally within the inner plexiform layer from axons of the bipolar cells to dendrites of the ganglion cells or to other amacrine cells.

Amacrine cells release GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine & indolamine.

Other neuronal cell types of the retina are:

  • The photoreceptors: rods & cones
  • Horizontal cells
  • Bipolar cells
  • Ganglion cells

Of these cell types, only neurotransmitters secreted by photoreceptors & amacrine cells have been discovered. Rods and cones release glutamate at their synapses with the bipolar cells.

questions.text: The only neurons in retina showing action potential are _____
questions.solution: All neural elements in the retina exhibit local graded potentials except ganglion cells which shows action potential.

questions.text: The fibers from contralateral nasal retina project to the following layers of lateral geniculate nucleus______
questions.solution: On each side, layers 1, 4, and 6 of the lateral geniculate nucleus receive input from the contralateral eye, whereas layers 2, 3, and 5 receive input from the ipsilateral eye. (Refer figure).

questions.text: Parvocellular pathway carries signal for detection of_____
questions.solution:
From the Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN), a magnocellular pathway (from layers 1 and 2) and a parvocellular pathway (from the rest of the layers) project to the visual cortex.

Parvocellular pathway Magnocellular pathway
Receive input entirely from type X retinal ganglion cells, and transmit color. Formed by Y ganglion cells project to magnocellular layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus.
Convey accurate point-to-point spatial information. Colorblind, transmitting only black-and-white information.
Terminate in layer 4C of the primary visual cortex. Terminate in layer 4C of the primary visual cortex.
Carries signals for color vision, texture, shape, and fine details. Carries signals for detection of movement, depth, and flicker.

questions.text: The axons from lateral geniculate nucleus terminate in _____ layer of primary visual cortex.
questions.solution:
The axons from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) mostly end in layer 4.

The primary visual receiving area (primary visual cortex) is located principally on the sides of the calca­rine fissure and has 6 layers similar to the neocortex. Layer 4 recieves most of the input from the LGN, which is divided further into 4A, 4B, 4Cα, and 4Cβ.

The magnocellular pathways from layers 1 and 2 of the LGN end in layer 4Cα while the parvocellular pathways from layers 3-6 of the LGN end in layer 4Cβ.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist explains to a patient that he is a protanope. These patients have difficulty in identifying which of the following color?
questions.solution:
Protanopes are dichromats with difficulty in identifying red color.

  • Anomalous Trichromatic Vision
    • Deficiency of red is Protanomaly.
    • Deficiency of green is Deuteranomaly.
    • Deficiency of blue is Tritanomaly.
  • Dichromatic Vision (Individuals with only two cone systems)
    • Blindness to red color Protanopia (Protanope).
    • Blindness to green color Deuteranopia (Deuteranope).
    • Blindness to blue color Tritanopia (Tritanope).
  • Monochromatic Vision Have only one cone system.
  • Color blindness is X-linked recessive.
  • Achromatopsia/ Achromasia- Color blindness is due to lesions of area V8 of the visual cortex.

questions.text: Auditory information is relayed through ______ thalamic nucleus.
questions.solution:
The medial geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys auditory information from the brainstem to the primary auditory cortex.

Lateral geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys visual information.

Related Pearl: Central Auditory Pathway

E.Coli - MA (mnemonic)

Eighth nerve 

Cochlear nuclei 

Olivary complex 

Lateral lemniscus 

Inferior colliculus 

Medial geniculate body 

Auditory cortex

Most of the primary auditory cortex is in the temporal lobe, but the association cortices extend over much of the insular lobe and even onto the lateral portion of the parietal lobe.

questions.text: In the auditory pathway, which is the first structure that can determine the direction of the perceived sound?
questions.solution:
The superior olivary nuclei receive information from both ears and begin the process of detecting the direction from which a sound comes.

The eighth nerves reach their respective cohlear nuclei in the medulla from where the nerves travel to both the ipsilateral and contralteral superior olivary nuclei in the pons and hence giving it the ability to detect the direction of the sound.

The lateral part of superior olivary nucleus does so by comparing the difference in intensities of sound reaching the two ears, whereas the medial part of the superior olivary nucleus detects the time lag between the signals entering the two ears.

questions.text: Which of the following events prompts the auditory system to interpret a sound as loud?

choices.text: Decreased number of inner hair cells become stimulated
Decreased number of outer hair cells become stimulated
Hair cells excite nerve endings at a diminished rate
Amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases

questions.solution:
There are at least three ways that the auditory system determines loudness:

  • As the sound becomes louder- the amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases so that hair cells excite the nerve endings at more rapid rates.
  • As the amplitude increases- more and more hair cells on the fringes of the resonating portion of the basilar membrane become stimulated.
  • As the amplitude of vibration reaches high intensity, the outer hair cells become recruited at a significant rate.

questions.text: Umami taste is evoked by____
questions.solution:
Umami taste is triggered particularly by the monosodium glutamate (MSG) used so extensively in Asian cooking.

Taste Receptors

  • Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter and umami.
  • The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:
    • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): for salt and sour taste
    • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): for sweet, bitter and umami
  • Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC →salt taste
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2 and T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) → Umami

questions.text: Mitral cells are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Mitral cells are seen in Olfactory bulb.

Axons of Olfactory nerves (First cranial nerve) synapse with the mitral cells and tufted cells in the olfactory bulb to form anatomically discrete units called olfactory glomeruli.

The olfactory bulb also contains periglomerular cells that are inhibitory interneurons and granule cells that make reciprocal synapses with mitral and tufted cells.

These mitral and tufted cells (second-order neurons) terminate in Olfactory cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory systems has the smallest range of intensity discrimination?
questions.solution:
The olfactory system has the smallest range of intensity discrimination.

Smell is concerned more with detecting the presence or absence of odors , than with the quantitative detection of their intensities. Concentrations that are only 10 to 50 times above threshold values will evoke maximum intensity of smell, which is in contrast to most other sensory system of the body.

questions.text: Number of cones in the retina (millions) is_______
questions.solution:
There are approximately 6 million cones and 120 million rods in each human eye.

Features of Photoreceptors

  • Each rod and cone are divided into outer segment, inner segment, nuclear region and a synaptic zone.
  • Saccules and discs in the outer segment contain photosensitive pigments.
  • If a person spends a considerable length of time in brightly lighted surroundings and then moves to a dimly lighted environment, the retinas slowly become “accustomed to the dark.” This decline in visual threshold is known as dark adaptation. It is nearly maximal in about 20 min, much longer than the time taken for light adaptation which is 5 min.
  • When one passes suddenly from a dim to a brightly lighted environment, the light seems intensely and even uncomfortably bright until the eyes adapt to the increased illumination and the visual threshold rises. This adaptation occurs over a period of about 5 min and is called light adaptation. 

Related Pearl: Differences between Rods and Cones

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the light reflex, where, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while stimulating the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumours of the optic thalamus.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.
